speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: SCENE II. Venice. A street.

speaker: MOROCCO
text_entry: Enter LAUNCELOT

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: this Jew my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: tempts me saying to me 'Gobbo, Launcelot Gobbo, good

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Launcelot,' or 'good Gobbo,' or good Launcelot

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Gobbo, use your legs, take the start, run away. My

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: conscience says 'No; take heed,' honest Launcelot;

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: take heed, honest Gobbo, or, as aforesaid, 'honest

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Launcelot Gobbo; do not run; scorn running with thy

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: heels.' Well, the most courageous fiend bids me

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: pack: 'Via!' says the fiend; 'away!' says the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fiend; 'for the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,'

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: says the fiend, 'and run.' Well, my conscience,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: to me 'My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: man's son,' or rather an honest woman's son; for,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: indeed, my father did something smack, something

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: grow to, he had a kind of taste; well, my conscience

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: says 'Launcelot, budge not.' 'Budge,' says the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fiend. 'Budge not,' says my conscience.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: 'Conscience,' say I, 'you counsel well;' ' Fiend,'

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: say I, 'you counsel well:' to be ruled by my

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: conscience, I should stay with the Jew my master,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil; and, to

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: himself. Certainly the Jew is the very devil

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: incarnal; and, in my conscience, my conscience is

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: friendly counsel: I will run, fiend; my heels are

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: at your command; I will run.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Enter Old GOBBO, with a basket

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: to master Jew's?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: [Aside]  O heavens, this is my true-begotten father!

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: who, being more than sand-blind, high-gravel blind,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: knows me not: I will try confusions with him.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: to master Jew's?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: at the next turning of all, on your left; marry, at

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: the very next turning, turn of no hand, but turn

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: down indirectly to the Jew's house.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: By God's sonties, 'twill be a hard way to hit. Can

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: you tell me whether one Launcelot,

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Aside

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Mark me now; now will I raise the waters. Talk you

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: of young Master Launcelot?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: No master, sir, but a poor man's son: his father,

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: though I say it, is an honest exceeding poor man

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: and, God be thanked, well to live.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Well, let his father be what a' will, we talk of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: young Master Launcelot.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Your worship's friend and Launcelot, sir.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: talk you of young Master Launcelot?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Of Launcelot, an't please your mastership.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Launcelot, father; for the young gentleman,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: according to Fates and Destinies and such odd

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: sayings, the Sisters Three and such branches of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: learning, is indeed deceased, or, as you would say

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: in plain terms, gone to heaven.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Marry, God forbid! the boy was the very staff of my

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: age, my very prop.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: a prop? Do you know me, father?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman:

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: but, I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: soul, alive or dead?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Do you not know me, father?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind; I know you not.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Nay, indeed, if you had your eyes, you might fail of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: the knowing me: it is a wise father that knows his

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: own child. Well, old man, I will tell you news of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your son: give me your blessing: truth will come

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: to light; murder cannot be hid long; a man's son

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: may, but at the length truth will out.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Pray you, sir, stand up: I am sure you are not

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Launcelot, my boy.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Pray you, let's have no more fooling about it, but

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: give me your blessing: I am Launcelot, your boy

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: that was, your son that is, your child that shall

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: be.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: I cannot think you are my son.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: I know not what I shall think of that: but I am

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Launcelot, the Jew's man, and I am sure Margery your

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: wife is my mother.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Her name is Margery, indeed: I'll be sworn, if thou

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Lord worshipped might he be! what a beard hast thou

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: got! thou hast got more hair on thy chin than

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: It should seem, then, that Dobbin's tail grows

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: backward: I am sure he had more hair of his tail

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: than I have of my face when I last saw him.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: master agree? I have brought him a present. How

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: 'gree you now?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Well, well: but, for mine own part, as I have set

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: have run some ground. My master's a very Jew: give

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: him a present! give him a halter: I am famished in

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: his service; you may tell every finger I have with

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come: give me

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your present to one Master Bassanio, who, indeed,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: gives rare new liveries: if I serve not him, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: will run as far as God has any ground. O rare

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: fortune! here comes the man: to him, father; for I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: am a Jew, if I serve the Jew any longer.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO, with LEONARDO and other followers

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You may do so; but let it be so hasted that supper

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: be ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: these letters delivered; put the liveries to making,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Exit a Servant

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: To him, father.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: God bless your worship!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Gramercy! wouldst thou aught with me?

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: Here's my son, sir, a poor boy,--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man; that

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: would, sir, as my father shall specify--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Indeed, the short and the long is, I serve the Jew,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: and have a desire, as my father shall specify--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: His master and he, saving your worship's reverence,

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: are scarce cater-cousins--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being, I

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you--

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: your worship, and my suit is--

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: your worship shall know by this honest old man; and,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: One speak for both. What would you?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Serve you, sir.

speaker: GOBBO
text_entry: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I know thee well; thou hast obtain'd thy suit:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And hath preferr'd thee, if it be preferment

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To leave a rich Jew's service, to become

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The follower of so poor a gentleman.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: The old proverb is very well parted between my

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: master Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: God, sir, and he hath enough.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thou speak'st it well. Go, father, with thy son.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Take leave of thy old master and inquire

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My lodging out. Give him a livery

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: More guarded than his fellows': see it done.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no; I have

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: ne'er a tongue in my head. Well, if any man in

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: upon a book, I shall have good fortune. Go to,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: here's a simple line of life: here's a small trifle

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: of wives: alas, fifteen wives is nothing! eleven

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: man: and then to 'scape drowning thrice, and to be

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: in peril of my life with the edge of a feather-bed;

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: here are simple scapes. Well, if Fortune be a

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: woman, she's a good wench for this gear. Father,

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: come; I'll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling of an eye.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Exeunt Launcelot and Old Gobbo

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: These things being bought and orderly bestow'd,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Return in haste, for I do feast to-night

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My best-esteem'd acquaintance: hie thee, go.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: My best endeavours shall be done herein.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Enter GRATIANO

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Where is your master?

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Yonder, sir, he walks.

speaker: LEONARDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Signior Bassanio!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Gratiano!

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I have a suit to you.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You have obtain'd it.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You must not deny me: I must go with you to Belmont.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Why then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Parts that become thee happily enough

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And in such eyes as ours appear not faults;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: But where thou art not known, why, there they show

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Something too liberal. Pray thee, take pain

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To allay with some cold drops of modesty

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I be misconstrued in the place I go to,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And lose my hopes.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Signior Bassanio, hear me:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: If I do not put on a sober habit,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Talk with respect and swear but now and then,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demurely,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Thus with my hat, and sigh and say 'amen,'

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Use all the observance of civility,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Like one well studied in a sad ostent

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: To please his grandam, never trust me more.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Well, we shall see your bearing.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Nay, but I bar to-night: you shall not gauge me

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: By what we do to-night.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No, that were pity:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I would entreat you rather to put on

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That purpose merriment. But fare you well:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I have some business.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And I must to Lorenzo and the rest:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But we will visit you at supper-time.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Exeunt
